push.translation[0].definitions[0].defin: to make someone or something move by pressing them with your hands, arms etc
push.translation[0].definitions[0].examp: It didn’t move, so she pushed harder.
I promised to push him on the swings for as long as he wanted.
I slowly pushed the door open.
Maria pushed her hair back from her forehead.
Philip pushed him towards the door.
push.translation[0].definitions[1].defin: to press a button, switch etc in order to make a piece of equipment start or stop working
push.translation[0].definitions[1].examp: I got in and pushed the button for the fourth floor.
Push the green button to start the engine.
push.translation[0].definitions[2].defin: to use your hands, arms etc to make people or things move, so that you can get past them
push.translation[0].definitions[2].examp: Don’t push. Everyone will get a turn.
A fat man pushed past me in his rush to leave.
She pushed her way to the front.
push.translation[0].definitions[3].defin: to encourage or force someone to do something or to work hard
push.translation[0].definitions[3].examp: Encourage your kids to try new things, but try not to push them too hard.
athletes who push their bodies to the limit
He’s been pushing himself too hard, working 12-hour days.
My husband pushed me into leaving the job.
The teachers pushed the students to achieve.
push.translation[0].definitions[4].defin: to try to persuade people to accept your ideas, opinions etc in order to achieve something
push.translation[0].definitions[4].examp: The president is trying to push his agenda in Congress.
He was pushing hard for welfare reform.
Company representatives are pushing to open foreign markets to their products.
We don’t try to push our religion on anyone.
push.translation[0].definitions[5].defin: to change someone’s situation, or to make a situation change, especially when some people do not want it to change
push.translation[0].definitions[5].examp: The law would push even more children into poverty.
attempts to push the peace process forward
push.translation[0].definitions[6].defin: to increase or decrease an amount, value, or number
push.translation[0].definitions[6].examp: New technology has pushed the cost of health care even higher.
Slow sales have pushed down orders.
push.translation[0].definitions[7].defin: if an army pushes somewhere, it moves in that direction
push.translation[0].definitions[7].examp: We pushed deep into enemy territory.
push.translation[0].definitions[8].defin: to try to sell more of a product by advertising it a lot
push.translation[0].definitions[8].examp: Sports stars earn big bucks for pushing everything from shoes to soft drinks.
push.translation[0].definitions[10].defi: to automatically send your email to your smartphone, so that you receive it immediately
push.translation[0].note_box[0].sections: to make something or someone move by pressing them with your hands, arms etc
Push the door, don’t pull it.
She pushed him away and walked out.
shove
to push someone or something in a rough or careless way
People were shoving to get to the front of the queue.
Tom shoved his suitcase under the bed.
stuff
to push something quickly and carelessly into a small space
She stuffed a few clothes into a bag and left.
poke
to push someone or something with your finger or something sharp
I poked the snake with a stick but it was dead.
nudge
to push someone beside you gently with your elbow to get their attention
Toby nudged me and pointed out of the window.
roll
to push something round or something on wheels so that it moves forward
They rolled the logs down the hill.
The car still didn’t start so we tried to roll it off the road.
wheel
to push something with wheels, for example a bicycle or a trolley, so that it moves forward, while guiding it with your hands
Rob wheeled his bike round the back of the house.
push.translation[1].definitions[0].examp: Jodi had stopped swinging. ‘Want a push?’ her dad asked.
If the door’s stuck, just give it a push.
Files can be attached to your email at the push of a button.
at/with the push of a button
push.translation[1].definitions[1].defin: when someone, especially a business, tries to get or achieve something
push.translation[1].definitions[1].examp: The company has recently made a big push into the Japanese market.
a push to attract new members
push.translation[1].definitions[2].defin: if someone gives someone else a push, they encourage or persuade them to try something
push.translation[1].definitions[2].examp: She just needed a gentle push to get her to join in.
push.translation[1].definitions[3].defin: a planned military movement into the area where the enemy is
push.translation[1].definitions[3].examp: The army has made another big push into enemy territory.
push.translation[2].definitions[0].defin: to work hard to persuade people to buy more of a product, for example by advertising it a lot
push.translation[2].definitions[0].examp: Our sales staff will be pushing the new model hard.
IBM will use its huge sales force to push this product.
push.translation[2].definitions[1].defin: to try to get people to accept an idea, proposal etc
push.translation[2].definitions[1].examp: Manufacturing groups are pushing a federal products liability law to limit punitive damages.
push.translation[3].definitions[0].defin: a period of determined effort in business, especially one in which you gain an advantage over your opponents
push.translation[3].definitions[0].examp: The company recently made a big push into the Japanese market.
push.translation[3].definitions[1].defin: to make someone leave their job, especially because they have done something wrong
push.translation[3].definitions[1].examp: So they gave you the push, did they? You’re so lazy, I’m not surprised!
push.translation[4].definitions[0].defin: on the Internet, push systems deliver information, advertising etc to your computer without you having to ask for it to be DOWNLOADED
